comms_internal: Source: txt (Sunik 1985: txt 7). 1) tsd: əj xusə piktə-ǯi bā-la ŋənə-m ičə-xəm-bi [this male child-ins outside-loc go-cvb.sim.sg see-pst-1sg] 'Я увидела этого мальчика, идя по улице' (piktəǯi (INS) - a speech failure? ACC is expected); 2) ipr: bi nanǯin čaqčaxar bā-la bāča-xam [I s/he.ins coming_across outside-loc meet-pst.1sg] ‘Я с ним случайно встретился на улице’ (NOM_INS); Sunik 1985: бāчуву - встретиться, состязаться (I'm not sure that it really has the meaning 'to come across'); ачалуву 'встретить'; texts: 'to come across' is expressed by baqa- ('to find') and ačala-, both TR.
Source: elicitation, tsd. xadgu-ti [house-lat] - ок

sentence: tara ti mərgən mə̄n ǯai mokčo-mokčo opa-wan-da
glosses_en: then that hero self birch_boat bent become-CAUS-CVB.NSIM
back_translation_en: ‘Then this hero bent his birch boat.’

comms_internal: Source: txt (Sunik 1985: txt 1). [bent become.CAUS] comment: Non-verbal predicate. The direct object is unmarked. An example proposed by the consultant: Xusə piktə mō-wa pəjsi op-an-či-ni [male child tree-acc down become-caus-pst-3sg] ‘Мальчик пригнул ветку вниз (к земле)’ (tsd). Sunik 1985: муримбуву 'согнуть (палку, железо и т. п.)' (not attested in texts).

sentence: xusə piktə əktə piktə-ti wən-či-n: ńimər-u min-ti!

comms: Not quite exact translation of the stimulus sentence.
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to land'. NOM_LAT-POSTP is also possible: cf. sapsi kera-ti-ni [bank edge-lat-3sg] ‘на берег’ / nā=bani [ground=to] ‘на землю’ (tsd). The verb xā- has a narrow meaning ‘to land, to reach (the bank)’. There is a verb with a more general meaning, i.e. isi- ‘to reach’. Its valency pattern varies between NOM_ACC and NOM_LAT, cf. textual examples. Puǯi, xawli mun tə̄-wə-pu isi-xa-si [beauty anyhow our homeland-acc-1pl reach-pst-2sg] 'Девица, ты все же нашей родины достигла' (Sunik 1985: txt 5); Um bāčan-ti isi-xa-ni [one island-lat reach-pst-3sg] 'До одного острова дошел' (Sunik 1985: txt 1).

back_translation_en: ‘This boy touched the wall with his hand.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The body-part participant (‘with his hand’) seems to be optional but preferable.

back_translation_en: ‘This boy is fighting with the girl.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [fight.REC]. Cf. 23: sori-, sormači- ''fight, have a quarrel'. Another pattern: INS_INS (V-pl): xusə piktə-ǯi əktə piktə-ǯi sor-mač-i-ti 'Мальчик с девочкой ссорятся (tsd). INS_INS is a standard subject coordination pattern.

back_translation_en: ‘This boy is friends with the girl.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. ipr: the following verbs are also possible: andala-, ačaǯi- (not attested in Sunik 1985), xupi- ('play'); all with the NOM_INS pattern.

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The habitual interpretation instead of the progressive one (this does not influence argument structure).

sentence: ami-ni mə̄n piktə-ji ńī-ǯi sori-n turgun-dulə-ni gosla-xa-ni
glosses_en: father-3SG self child-REFL.SG person-INS fight-3SG cause-LOC-3SG criticize-PST-3SG
back_translation_en: ‘Father scolded his son for a fight with other people.’
glosses_ru: отец-3SG свой ребенок-REFL.SG человек-INS драться-3SG причина-LOC-3SG ругать-PST-3SG
back_translation_ru: ‘Отец отругал своего сына за драку с людьми’.
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. "ńīǯi sorin turgunduləni" is optional. Gosila- is rather ‘criticize’ than ‘punish’. Sunik 1985: сиǯелчуву ‘проучить, наказать, замучить’.

comms: Not included in the database because Y cannot be overtly expressed. Non-verbal predicate.

Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [find.REP].

comms: Arguably, this is an elliptical structure, the third implicit argument is 'money' (encoded by the nominative case when overt).
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [reach.NEG]. reach/be_enough'+NEG. The main valency pattern is DAT_NOM rather than DAT_DAT: Y seems to represent the ellipsis process: (ǯaxa) taŋgu-du isəsini [(money) hundred-dat reach-conneg-prs.neg-3sg] 'Денег (NOM) не хватает в количестве сотни (DAT)', cf. the next example with aboli-. One more variant: aboli- (the first argument is manifested as a noun phrase adjunct / as a possessive affix): Ǯaxa-n um taŋgun-du abol-i-ni [money-3sg one thousand-dat lack-prs-3sg] ‘букв.: Из его денег не хватает сотни’ (tsd); Ti bi-m ǯaxa-n abuli-mi [so be-cvb.sim.sg money-3sg lack-cvb.sim.sg] 'Поэтому денег у него не хватает' (ipr).
Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to hate, despise'. mə̄n nəwuji [self younger_brother-refl.sg] ‘своего младшего брата’. Cf. 126.
Source: elicitation, tsd. The first variant (tsd) is with tətu-ni (unmarked: [cloth-3sg]) NOM~ACC variation in the DO-position (is not expected here) or a calque from Russian (more probable)?

comms: This is an impersonal construction.
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [search.IMPS]. Gələu is the impersonal form derived from the verb 'search, ask for'. Probably, it is grammaticalized to some extent. The Y-argument ('money') is expected to occupy the DO position (ACC~unmarked) if this is still a standard impersonal construction. However, it might be rather nominative if the construction with gələu is highly grammaticalized.

comms: Non-verbal predicate.

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, ipr. The verb literally means 'to be'. tsd: One more variant with 3 arguments: əj xotom-ba xərəlum qorča-ǯi kərən-či-ti [this town-acc around wall-ins ?-pst-3pl] 'Этот город окружили стенами' (tsd)
Source: elicitation, ipr. The verb literally means 'to be redundant'. A possible calque from Russian. tsd: without the X-argument. Sunik 1985: пулэдюву ‘быть лишним’ (пулэ 'излишек').

comms: This example is taken from natural texts.
sentence: əldəŋgə, əldəŋgə, xawli ńī-ti ǯaral-i ta-m o-či-ni
glosses_en: interesting interesting anyway human-LAT answer-PRS do-CVB.SIM.SG become-PST-3SG
back_translation_en: ‘Interesting, interesting, [he] even learned how to speak (lit. became the one who answers the man).’
glosses_ru: интересно интересно все_таки человек-LAT отвечать-PRS делать-CVB.SIM.SG стать-PST-3SG
back_translation_ru: ‘Интересно, интересно, даже человеку отвечающим стал (научился говорить)’.
comms_internal: Source: txt (Sunik 1985: txt 2). The consultants used the verb wən- 'say' (NOM_LAT-case): Xusə piktə učitelj-ti wən-či-ni [male child teacher-lat say-pst-3sg] 'Мальчик ответил (сказал) учителю' (tsd).

comms: This example is taken from natural texts.
back_translation_en: ‘[We] opened the ABC book and put it like this.’
comms_internal: Source: txt (spd). The verb ńī- has a wide neutral meaning 'open', but I am not sure that this verb can be used with such arguments as 'tin'; its most common arguments are 'door' and 'eyes'. Translations by the consultants with the verb ačo- 'take off' (TR): əńiə al'u kumta-n aču-xa-n [mother vessel cover take_off-pst-3sg] 'Мать открыла кастрюлю (букв. сняла крышку кастрюли)' (ipr). Əj xusə piktə banka-wa ačo-xa-ni [this male child tin-acc take_off-pst-3sg] 'Мальчик открыл банку (букв. снял банку)' (tsd) (a more dubitous example). Sunik 1985: дэгбэлуву 'открыть (банку), вырвать (камень из земли)' (not attested in texts).

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to be different'.

comms: Not included in the database because Y cannot be overtly expressed.

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to break, plough'. The meaning ‘plough’ is attested in Sunik 1985; the Russian verb paxa- (TR) is also used.

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to stink'. The verb 'to stink' (not attested in Sunik 1985, waksa – ‘nose’). Another variant: min ŋāla-j sugdata pūŋ-ču [my hand-1.sg fish smell-propr] 'Мои руки пахнут рыбой (букв. с запахом рыбы)' (ipr).

sentence: ti asi-n ... ti ən-bə-n bələč-i, mama-wa bələč-i
glosses_en: that wife-3SG ... that mother-ACC-3SG help-PRS old_woman-ACC help-PRS
back_translation_en: ‘This wife of his helps his mother, helps the old woman.’

back_translation_ru: ‘Эта его жена его матери помогает, старухе помогает’.
comms_internal: Source: txt (oab). Both speakers proposed the NOM_DAT pattern, which seems to be a calque from Russian; tsd also proposed a variant with NOM_LAT (further it was rejected). Ami-n mə̄n piktə-du bələči-xə-n əj dale-wa əuru-mi [father-3sg self child-dat help-pst-3sg this bag-acc lift-cvb.sim.sg] 'Отец помог сыну поднять этот мешок' (tsd). Texts: both uses with TR and NOM_DAT are attested.
Source: elicitation, tsd. This particular sentence can actually refer to any level of language proficiency
Source: elicitation, ipr. Another variant with the verb 'to enter' (NOM_LAT): Agdi xagdu-ti pos ī-xə-ni [thunder house-lat throughout enter-pst-3sg] ‘Молния попала в дом (прошла насквозь)’ (tsd).

back_translation_en: ‘This boy hurt himself with a razor.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [cut REFL]. 3 arguments (ipr: the intransitive use of bajla-; Sunik 1985: 'ранить (человека, зверя, птицу'); )

back_translation_en: ‘The vessel (cup/plate) got stuck to the table.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. NOM_LAT is also possible: dərə=bən ~ dərə-ti

comms: Not included in the database because Y cannot be overtly expressed. This example is taken from natural texts.
back_translation_en: ‘And the hero lost the people of the underwater world.’
comms_internal: Source: txt (sem_zpl). texts: no examples with both participants expressed; ipr: remembers the verb, but cannot recall the valency pattern; tsd: "This meaning cannot be expressed".

comms: Not included in the database because arguably inanimate Y cannot be overtly expressed. This example is taken from natural texts.
back_translation_en: ‘[They] are glad about their child, this little frog.’
comms_internal: Source: txt (Sunik 1985: txt 9). The examples proposed by speakers: Nan min bitxə-wə-j bāqa-ra, bārača-xa-n [s/he my letter-acc-1sg find-cvb.nsim be_glad-pst-3sg] 'Он обрадовался моему письму (букв. получив мое письмо)' (ipr); Ama sin uj-ǯu-xə-s bitxə-wə baqa-xan-du tə̄s bārači-xa-ni [father your tie-rep-pst-2sg letter-acc find-pst-dat very be_glad-pst-3sg] 'Отец очень обрадовался твоему письму (=тому, что получил завернутое тобой письмо)' (tsd), NOM_DAT, a clausal argument, a probable calque from Russian. Texts: no uses with the NOM_DAT pattern, a couple of uses with the TR pattern (all of them contain the amimate argument); many examples with "CVB + Subject be_glad" (cf. the example from ipr). UPD: еще раз посмотрела тексты - этот пример и еще пара похожих, тоже с аккузативом, вполне убедительные, но все с одушевленным участником. сам глагол очень частотный, но чаще всего употребляется как одиночное деепричастие - радуясь, что-то делать. можно, наверное, оставить пример, но написать, что не включен. потому что одушевленный участник
Source: elicitation, tsd.

back_translation_en: ‘This woman gave birth to a son.’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to find'. One-word nonspecific object => DEST (piktə-ǯu-j [child-dest-refl]), Multi-word / specific object => ACC (xusə piktə-wə [male child-acc]. A textual example with DEST: Tawanči ti bi-či-ti, piktə-ǯu-j=də baqa-xa, xusə piktə baqa-xa [since_then so be-pst-3pl child-dest-refl.sg=emph find-pst male child find-pst] ‘С тех пор так и жили, и ребенка (она) родила, мальчика родила’. (Sunik 1985: txt 5)
Source: elicitation, tsd.
Source: elicitation, tsd.
Source: elicitation, tsd. Sunik 1985: гочуву 'скучать'

sentence: əj iŋda min xami-ki-je ti pul-s-i-ni
glosses_en: this dog my behind-PROL-1SG so walk-IPFV-PRS-3SG
glosses_ru: этот собака мой сзади-PROL-1SG так гулять-IPFV-PRS-3SG
back_translation_ru: ‘Эта собака следует за мной по пятам’.
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to walk'. Min xamikij ŋənəu ‘Следуйте за мной!’ (tsd). One more variant: xasi- 'follow, pursue (TR)' (with a negative nuance). Ulə əkə-səl xas-i-ti namban [good woman-pl pursue-prs-3pl s/he.acc] 'Красивые девушки за ними едут' (txt_spk). Sunik 1985: вэрулǯиву 'следовать, идти следом' (attested in texts with no arguments except for Subject).
Source: elicitation, tsd. Sunik 1985: хулумбуву ‘вылезать, выходить (из лодки, парохода и т.п.)’.

Source: elicitation, tsd. Here, the direct object takes the unmarked form, the accusative case is also possible. One more example: Ama jajam-ba dosoǯ-i-ni raǯio-ǯi [father song-acc listen-prs-3sg radio-ins] ‘Отец слушает песню по радио’ (tsd).

comms: Not included in the database because this translation is semantically inaccurate and Y is expressed as an NP-internal modifier.
back_translation_en: ‘This boy listens to his mother (lit. his mother’s words).’
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to listen'. Sunik 1985: дāбуву 'слушаться, подчиняться', дахурсуву 'соглашаться, подчиняться'. Texts: Nan wən-di-wə-n daxar-i-pu [s/he say-prs-acc-3sg agree-prs-1pl] 'Со всем, что она говорит, соглашаемся' (TR: another meaning, clausal argument)
Source: elicitation, tsd.
Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [mix.DECAUS]. mix+DECAUS. Solipkini is expected (solikpini sounds rather like a Nanai variant).

Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [see.RES]. The lative encoding is also possible: Bā=ban ičə-ǯ-i=n [sky=to see-res-prs-3sg] 'Он смотрит на небо' [NOM_LAT] (ipr). Both the lative and accusative valency patterns are attested in texts. Textual examples: Tal ti ila sium-ba ičə-ǯ-əč [then that three sun-acc see-res-cond] 'Потом на эти три солнца посмотрев...' [TR] (sem_pld); Xərəkə-mə piktə-n ǯaqpa-du-n bi-m, ən-ti ičə-ǯə-m, kuə-kuə xə̄rs-i-n [frog-adj child-3sg near-dat-3sg be-cvb.sim.sg mother-lat see-res-cvb.sim.sg croak-croak call-prs-3sg] 'Лягушка-ребенок, вблизи находясь, на мать смотрит, ква-ква зовет'. [NOM_LAT-CASE] (Sunik 1985: txt 9). The pattern NOM_LAT might be a calque from Russian, so I included the TR pattern in the database as the main one.
Source: elicitation, tsd. Ńučkə piktə tətuwən aču! [child cloth-acc-3sg] 'Сними с ребенка рубашку!’ (tsd)

Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to be'. Difficulties with translation. Another variant (more common?), where X is a noun phrase modifier ('the price of this gun'): Əj mewti tama-ni um tangu [this gun price-3sg one thousand] 'Цена этой чашки тысяча (рублей)' (tsd).

Source: elicitation, ipr. The predicate is structurally [gun.VBLZ]. čorla- [TR] 'не попасть': ciŋdə-wə čor-la-xa [птица-acc мимо-vblz-pst] 'промахнулся мимо птицы' (ipr); tsd: əj bəjčińi əj gasa-wa čoar mewti-la-xa-ni [this hunter this duck-acc outside gun-vblz-pst-3sg] ''Этот охотник выстрелил в (эту) утку, но не попал (выстрелил в утку мимо)' (čoar – ‘мимо’; without čoar – ‘целится’ (???)).

comms: Not included in the database because this translation is semantically inaccurate. Mulu is a birch bark bucket.
comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The verb literally means 'to become'. tsd: about a stone: Ǯolo mū dōtini (mūti) tukuxəni 'Камень упал в воду (NOM_LAT)’; only about a human being: mūlən- (monovalent), the verb is derived from 'water', the argument 'water' cannot be expressed. Sunik 1985: дириву 'затонуть, погружаться в воду, заливать лодку' (not attested in texts).

sentence: ti ńī rəbalka-du=də ulə tamata gursəl-bə uləs-i bi-či-t=gun
glosses_en: that human fishing-DAT=EMPH good such people-ACC love-PRS be-PST-3PL=PTCL
back_translation_en: ‘... whoever was good at fishing, [everyone] liked such people.’
glosses_ru: that человек рыбалка-DAT=EMPH хороший такой люди-ACC любить-PRS быть-PST-3PL=PTCL
back_translation_ru: ‘... кто в рыбалке хорош, таких людей уважали’.
comms_internal: Source: txt (lk_nk). The verb literally means 'to love'. NB The imperfective past tense form. tsd: guǯələsini ‘жалеет, любит’ (TR) is also possible; ipr: taundin (TR) (lit. 'counts, reads') - not attested in texts; Sunik 1985: аясуву 'уважать, любить'.

comms: This example is taken from natural texts.
sentence: ńī mə̄p gal-i-wa-ni ti nəu-dumə wən-di-ni
glosses_en: human REFL.SG be_squeamish-PRS-ACC-3SG that young-SEL say-PRS-3SG
back_translation_en: ‘That younger one [= the bear] says that the human [= the woman] is squeamish about him’.
glosses_ru: человек REFL.SG брезговать-PRS-ACC-3SG тот молодой-SEL говорить-PRS-3SG
back_translation_ru: ‘Тот младший (медведь) говорит, что человек (женщина) им брезгует’.
comms_internal: Source: txt (Sunik 1985: txt 6). NB An animate Stimulus. No elicited data. Also adaqasi- 'пренебрегать, брезговать' (attested in texts without an overtly expressed Stimulus).

sentence: əj xusə piktə əj əktə piktə-wə uləsu-lu-xə-ni

comms_internal: Source: elicitation, tsd. The predicate is structurally [love.INCH]. love.INCH 'fall in love'

Source: elicitation, tsd. I am not sure that the context was understood correctly by the consultant and the Y-argument is not a Stimulus in this example ('He envies another man and wants to have this woman (as a wife)'?). The first variant: Nan əj meuti-wa ananas-i-ni [s/he this gun-acc envy-prs-3sg] ‘Он завидует этому ружью’ (tsd) . In texts, this verb also has a valency for Stimulus: Ti ajse-wa ananasu-m [that gold envy-cvb.sim.sg] 'Завидуя этому золоту' (txt_spd).
Source: elicitation, tsd. NOM_LAT-CASE is also possible: əńi-ti [mother-lat] - OK
